skill.name: combat-system-creator
skill.description: Create and modify combat system components for SHINOBI WAY game following the dual-system architecture (CombatCalculationSystem + CombatWorkflowSystem). Use when user wants to add new combat mechanics, damage formulas, status effects, mitigation logic, turn phases, or refactor existing combat code. Guides through proper separation of pure calculations vs state management.
skill.summary: Create and modify combat system components for SHINOBI WAY game following the dual-system architectu...
skill.author: CesarAugustusGroB

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing reference materials and guides for implementing combat systems. No executable code, network calls, or file system access detected. The skill provides architectural patterns, formulas, and implementation guidelines for a turn-based combat system.

content.user_title: Build Turn-Based Combat Systems with Pure Functions
content.value_statement: Combat systems often mix calculation logic with state management, making them hard to test and balance. This skill provides a proven dual-system architecture that separates pure combat math from state mutations, enabling easier testing, debugging, and balance adjustments.
actual_capabilities: Creates pure calculation functions with no side effects
Implements state workflow handlers for combat phases
Generates damage formulas with elemental interactions
Designs status effect systems with proper mitigation pipelines
Provides architectural patterns for testable combat code
limitations: Specific to SHINOBI WAY game architecture

use_cases.title: Implement New Damage Types
use_cases.description: Add piercing, armor-break, or true damage mechanics with proper defense calculations and mitigation pipeline integration.

use_cases.title: Balance Combat Formulas
use_cases.description: Modify damage multipliers, critical rates, or defense soft caps while maintaining game balance and testability.

use_cases.title: Refactor Legacy Combat Code
use_cases.description: Separate mixed calculation/state code into pure functions and workflow handlers for better architecture.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Damage Skill
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a fire-element ninjutsu skill called 'Fireball' that scales with Spirit stat, deals 2.5x damage, has 15% crit bonus, and applies Burn DoT for 3 turns. Follow the dual-system architecture pattern.

prompt_templates.title: Status Effect System
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a Confusion status effect that gives 50% chance to hit self for half damage. Include calculation for self-hit chance and workflow integration for turn handling.

prompt_templates.title: Complex Mitigation
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement a shield buff that reflects 30% of incoming damage back to attacker before applying curse amplification. Include priority placement in mitigation pipeline.

prompt_templates.title: Combat Phase Extension
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a weather phase that applies random elemental damage to both combatants at turn end. Add calculation for weather damage and workflow integration.

output_examples.input: Create a lightning-element skill that chains to multiple enemies
output: Generated LightningChain skill with 2.0x Spirit scaling
Added chain damage calculation: 75% damage to secondary targets
Implemented pure calculation function for chain lightning math
Created workflow handler to apply damage to multiple targets
Added combat logs for chain lightning visualization

best_practices: Always separate pure calculations from state mutations for testability
Use complete result interfaces that capture all calculation data needed for workflows
Implement proper turn phase ordering with clear entry and exit conditions
Create reusable calculation functions that can be used for tooltips and AI preview
anti_patterns: Never mix damage calculations with HP modifications in the same function
Avoid hardcoding combat constants directly in calculation functions
Do not create circular dependencies between calculation and workflow systems
Never skip the mitigation pipeline order when adding new defensive mechanics

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with other game engines?
faq.answer: The architectural patterns are engine-agnostic, but the specific implementations reference SHINOBI WAY's TypeScript/React structure.

faq.question: Can I use this for real-time combat instead of turn-based?
faq.answer: The dual-system architecture works for any combat type, but the specific patterns and examples focus on turn-based mechanics.

faq.question: How do I integrate this with existing combat code?
faq.answer: Start by extracting pure calculations into CombatCalculationSystem, then gradually migrate state changes to CombatWorkflowSystem.

faq.question: Will this help with game balance testing?
faq.answer: Yes, pure calculation functions can be unit tested independently, making balance adjustments and regression testing much easier.

faq.question: What if I need to modify the damage pipeline?
faq.answer: The 5-step pipeline is modular - you can add new steps or modify existing ones while maintaining the separation principle.

faq.question: Does this include networking code for multiplayer?
faq.answer: No, this skill focuses on single-player combat mechanics. Multiplayer would require additional architecture for state synchronization.
